node.title: Introduction
node.p: This is the user manual for . It's still under construction.

The datatool package is able to save databases in its own internal format. Files in this format are difficult to edit and only apert should attempt it, but they are by far the fastest way of loading a datatool in . This application provides a making it easier to edit these files. It can also import data from files and from SQL databases. The application can run in either batch mode (default) or mode (see ). Command line invocation:

Available options:
(or -g)
Invoke in mode.
(or -b)
Invoke in batch mode (default).
filename (or -o filename)
Save the database to filename (batch mode only).
(or -v) Print the version details to STDOUT and exit. (or -h) Print a brief summary of available options to STDOUT and exit. csv file Import data from the given file. character Specify the character used to separate values in the file. (Defaults to acomma) character Specify the character used to delimit values in the file. (Defaults to adouble quote)
The file has a header row. (Default.)
The file doesn't have a header row. statement Import data from an SQL database where statement is an SQL SELECT statement. name The SQL database name. prefix The SQL prefix. (Default: jdbc:mysql://.) port The SQL port number. (Default: 3306.) host The SQL host. (Default: localhost.) user name The SQL user name. password The SQL password (insecure). If omitted, you will be prompted fora password if you try to import data from an SQL database.
For extra security, wipe the password from memory as soon as it has been used to connect to an SQL database.
Don't wipe the password from memory as soon as it has been used to connect to an SQL database. (Default.)

node.title: Graphical Mode
node.p: To run in graphical mode you must invoke it with the option.
The interface is currently very primitiveIt needs a lot of work on it! and doesn't allow you to do much, but let's test out afigure here (see ).

You can use the to create anew database (not yet implemented), load an existing database or import data. To load an existing database, use . To import data from a file use . To import data from a SQL database use . (Defaults to a database.)

Each column has a corresponding data type: string, integer, real or currency. (Currency type not yet implemented in the .) If one or more entries in a given column is a string (non-numerical) then the entire column has a string data type. If the column has no string entries, but has one or more real entries, then the entire column has a real data type. If there are no string or real entries, but there are one or more integer entries, then the entire column has an integer data type. If the column has no data, the type is unset.

Non-string entries can be edited by double-clicking on the relevant cell, or you can select the relevant cell and use . A cursor will appear in the cell and you can edit the numerical value. Press Enter to finish editing. To edit an entry in a column with the string data type, double-click on the relevant cell or select it and use to open the cell editor dialog box (see ).

node.title: Cell Editor
node.p: To open the cell editor dialog box (see ) double-click on the required cell, which must be in a column with a string data type. Alternatively, select the cell and use .
Once you have made your edits, click on to update the database. To discard the edits, click .

node.title: Info for Developers
node.p:
This chapter will be removed before release. In the tests directory there's a test file data-raw.dbtex (originally generated by datatool) and a test document test-doc.tex, a test file and a test SQL file. The SQL file can be used to create a test MySQL database. The batch mode can be tested using:
bin/datatooltk --out tests/test-out.dbtex tests/data-raw.dbtex bin/datatooltk --out tests/test-csv-out.dbtex --csv tests/test.csv
(The first command just reads in tests/data-raw.dbtex and writes it out as tests/test-out.dbtex. The second command imports data from tests/test.csv and saves it as tests/test-csv-out.dbtex.)

Once you have created the MySQL database, you can test it with:
bin/datatooltk --out tests/test-sql-data.dbtex \ --sql "SELECT * FROM testsqldata" --sqldb datatooltk --sqluser datatool
After you have completed these steps, you can the test document test-doc.tex.
